experimentDesign.title: Tether Blind Comparison Study
experimentDesign.hypothesis: Clinicians will prefer psychometrically-matched resource recommendations over logistics-matched recommendations when both are presented with identical formatting.
experimentDesign.primaryMetric: % of comparisons where participant selects the psychometrically-matched plan
experimentDesign.secondaryMetric: Qualitative themes in reasoning (do participants spontaneously cite psychometric factors?)
experimentDesign.presentation: Both plans show identical fields: resource name, tier, description, schedule, location/distance, cost, intake. No match rationale on either. Labels are 'Plan 1' and 'Plan 2' with randomized assignment.
experimentDesign.successThreshold: 70% preference for Version A across all cases

cases.presentingProblem: Second depressive episode. First episode 5 years ago, resolved without treatment. Current episode prompted by social isolation after relocation.
cases.currentTreatment: Sertraline 100mg daily, stabilized over past 6 weeks. Adherent to medication and appointments.
relevantHistory: Works remotely as customer service rep, Mon-Fri 9am-5pm
Moved to Roanoke 2 years ago for a relationship that ended
Lives alone in an apartment
Limited local social network
No substance use concerns
cases.functionalStatus: Low energy, especially evenings. Mornings are better. Working full-time but rarely leaves apartment outside of groceries.
patientReported: Says he knows he should get out more but finds most suggestions overwhelming
Tried one support group last year, described it as 'depressing' and didn't return
Used to enjoy hiking and being outdoors before the move but hasn't gone since
Prefers doing activities alongside others rather than face-to-face conversation
Open to short-term commitments but not ongoing obligations
cases.clinicalGoal: Increase social engagement and community connection to support recovery.
cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on morning energy pattern, preference for side-by-side activities, past hiking interest, aversion to traditional support group format, preference for short-term/drop-in commitment

recommendations.name: Blue Ridge Hiking Club - Beginner Group
recommendations.description: Weekly beginner-friendly group hikes on local trails. Casual pace with no experience required. Members range from 20s to 60s.
recommendations.intake: Drop-in, no registration required

recommendations.name: CBT Skills Group at Valley Behavioral Health
recommendations.description: Structured cognitive behavioral therapy skills group focused on behavioral activation and thought patterns. Led by licensed psychologist.
recommendations.intake: Referral from provider, next group starts in 2 weeks

recommendations.name: NAMI Peer-to-Peer Course
recommendations.description: Free 8-session educational program about mental health recovery taught by trained peers with lived experience.
recommendations.intake: Registration required, next session starts in 2 weeks

versionB.hidden_logic: Selected based on proximity, diagnosis category, insurance eligibility, and general availability

recommendations.name: Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance (DBSA) - Roanoke
recommendations.description: Peer-led support group for individuals living with depression or bipolar disorder. Open discussion format in a circle setting.
recommendations.intake: Drop-in, newcomers welcome

recommendations.name: Valley Community Mental Health Center - Outpatient Group Therapy
recommendations.description: Process-oriented group therapy for adults with mood disorders. Led by licensed clinical social worker. Ongoing enrollment.
recommendations.intake: Call to schedule intake appointment

recommendations.name: Roanoke Parks & Recreation - Adult Fitness Programs
recommendations.description: Various group fitness classes including yoga, aerobics, and strength training for adults. Classes held at multiple city recreation centers.
recommendations.intake: Register online or walk in

cases.presentingProblem: Chronic worry and physical tension escalating over the past year. Difficulty sleeping, muscle tension, GI complaints. Avoids social situations where she might be 'put on the spot.'
cases.currentTreatment: Escitalopram 10mg daily for 3 months. Starting to see improvement in baseline worry but still avoids most social situations. Seeing therapist biweekly for CBT.
relevantHistory: Works as a graphic designer at a small agency, mostly remote with occasional in-office days
Lives with her partner in an apartment
Moved from a larger city 18 months ago for partner's job
Left behind a close-knit friend group she misses
No substance use concerns
cases.functionalStatus: Functioning well at work (remote helps). Avoids crowded or unpredictable social settings. Tolerates small, structured groups better than large open ones. Evenings are when anxiety spikes most.
patientReported: Enjoys creative activities like drawing and ceramics but hasn't pursued them locally
Tried a large yoga class once but left early because it was too crowded and she felt watched
Prefers knowing exactly what to expect before showing up somewhere new
Comfortable one-on-one or in groups of 3-5 people
Mornings and early afternoons are her best times
cases.clinicalGoal: Gradual social re-engagement with structured, low-pressure activities that build tolerance without triggering avoidance.

clinicianSettings.contraindications: Avoid large-group or performance-based settings initially

cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on preference for small/structured groups, creative interests, need for predictability, morning/early afternoon energy, avoidance of crowded/unpredictable settings

recommendations.intake: Register online, class roster shared in advance

recommendations.description: Structured CBT-based group focused on anxiety management techniques. Closed group of 5-6 participants. Curriculum-driven with predictable session format.
recommendations.intake: Provider referral, pre-group orientation provided

recommendations.description: Weekly therapist-led group for adults with anxiety disorders. Focuses on coping strategies and peer support. 6-8 participants per group. Led by licensed clinical social worker.
recommendations.intake: Referral required, call to schedule

recommendations.description: Comprehensive outpatient anxiety treatment with individual and small-group therapy options. Multiple group formats available.
recommendations.intake: Call to schedule intake appointment

recommendations.description: Beginner-friendly yoga in a quiet studio room. Capped at 10 participants. Instructor-led with no partner work.
recommendations.intake: Walk-in welcome

cases.presentingProblem: Diagnosed at 19 during sophomore year after academic struggles. Medication has improved focus in class but social life and daily structure remain chaotic. Frequently forgets commitments, double-books, or signs up for things and never follows through.
cases.currentTreatment: Adderall XR 20mg daily, taken mornings. Sees psychiatrist monthly for medication management. No therapy currently.
relevantHistory: Senior at Virginia Tech, studying information technology
Lives in off-campus apartment with two roommates
Active socially but relationships are surface-level; struggles to maintain deeper friendships
Part-time job at campus IT help desk, 15 hours/week
No substance use concerns beyond occasional weekend drinking
cases.functionalStatus: Functions well when medicated (roughly 8am-4pm). Evenings are unstructured and unproductive. Hyperfocuses on video games late at night, disrupting sleep. Registration and scheduling tasks feel like major barriers.
patientReported: Loves hands-on activities, especially anything involving building or fixing things
Played intramural basketball freshman year but stopped because he kept forgetting game times
Gets bored quickly with anything repetitive or lecture-based
Prefers activities with immediate feedback rather than long-term goals
Hates paperwork, forms, and 'administrative overhead'
cases.clinicalGoal: Build structured routines outside of academics and find social outlets that accommodate ADHD-related challenges with follow-through and time management.
cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on preference for hands-on/novel activities, need for low administrative overhead, medication window (mornings best), history of drop-off with scheduling demands, preference for immediate engagement over long-term commitment

recommendations.name: NRV Makerspace - Open Build Hours
recommendations.description: Community workshop with 3D printers, laser cutters, woodworking tools, and electronics stations. Drop in anytime during open hours and work on whatever you want. Staff available to help.
recommendations.cost: Free for students with college ID
recommendations.intake: Walk in, sign liability waiver on first visit

recommendations.description: Informal pickup basketball games organized through a group chat. Games happen when enough people show up. No teams, no schedules, no season commitment.
recommendations.intake: Just show up, ask to join a game

recommendations.description: Monthly meetup for young adults with ADHD. Mix of education and peer sharing. Informal format, usually 8-12 people. Run by an adult with ADHD who is also a licensed counselor.
recommendations.schedule: First Saturday of each month, 11:00 AM, 90 minutes
recommendations.intake: Drop-in, no registration

versionB.hidden_logic: Selected based on proximity to campus, ADHD diagnosis category, student eligibility, and general availability

recommendations.description: Weekly facilitated group for students with ADHD. Process-oriented discussion of academic and social challenges. Led by a staff psychologist. Runs full semester.
recommendations.schedule: Mondays 4:00 PM, weekly, full semester commitment

recommendations.intake: Register online by season deadline, team draft night required

recommendations.description: 4-week workshop series on mindfulness techniques for improving focus and managing distraction. Lecture and guided practice format.
recommendations.intake: Register through student portal

cases.presentingProblem: Escalating drinking over 3 years following divorce. Averaging 6-8 drinks nightly. One DUI 8 months ago. Completed outpatient detox 60 days ago. Currently sober but struggling with evenings and weekends.
cases.currentTreatment: Naltrexone 50mg daily. Completed IOP 4 weeks ago. Sees psychiatrist biweekly. Attending therapy weekly.
relevantHistory: Works as an electrician, Mon-Fri 7am-3:30pm
Divorced, shares custody of two kids (ages 8 and 11), has them every other weekend
Lives alone in a rented townhouse
Drinking was primarily solitary, at home, evenings
Former college baseball player, stays physically active
cases.functionalStatus: Performing well at work. Evenings are the high-risk window. Has one close friend from work who drinks socially. Weekends without kids feel empty and dangerous. Physically capable and active.
patientReported: Says AA felt 'too religious' when he tried it once, but open to meeting other people in recovery
Misses the camaraderie of team sports
Wants to fill evening and weekend hours with something structured
Uncomfortable talking about feelings in groups, prefers activities where conversation happens naturally
Needs environments where alcohol is not present
cases.clinicalGoal: Build a sober social network and structured evening/weekend activities to reduce relapse risk during high-vulnerability windows.

clinicianSettings.contraindications: No environments where alcohol is served or present

cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as the treating psychiatrist.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on evening/weekend scheduling priority, preference for activity-based over talk-based, team sports background, resistance to spiritual framing, need for alcohol-free environments, preference for peer camaraderie

recommendations.location: Rescue Mission Community Room, 2.1 miles away

recommendations.description: Recreational co-ed softball league. Teams practice once a week and play one game per week. Post-game gatherings at a nearby park (no bar). Season is 8 weeks.
recommendations.intake: Register online, individuals placed on teams

recommendations.description: Structured skills-based group focused on identifying triggers and building coping strategies. CBT-oriented, led by licensed addiction counselor. Closed group of 6-8.
recommendations.intake: Provider referral, starts within 1 week

versionB.hidden_logic: Selected based on proximity, AUD diagnosis category, insurance eligibility, and general availability

cases.presentingProblem: Diagnosed at age 13 after increasing academic difficulties in middle school. Medication helps in school but afternoons and weekends are unstructured. Spends most free time alone on screens. Parents concerned about social isolation and lack of extracurriculars.
cases.currentTreatment: Concerta 36mg daily, taken before school. Sees psychiatrist every 2 months. No therapy currently. Parents involved in treatment.
relevantHistory: Sophomore at a public high school
Lives with both parents and a younger sister (age 12)
Had a small friend group in middle school that dispersed across different high schools
Grades are average (B/C) with medication but homework completion is inconsistent
No behavioral issues, described as 'quiet and easygoing' by teachers
cases.functionalStatus: Medication effective roughly 7am-3pm. Afternoons are unmedicated and unstructured. Spends 4-6 hours daily on YouTube and gaming. Socially passive: won't initiate plans but will participate if someone else organizes. Parents do most of the executive function scaffolding at home.
patientReported: Likes building things, especially Legos and Minecraft
Interested in computers and coding but hasn't tried formal classes
Tried soccer in 6th grade but quit because practices felt too long and repetitive
Would rather do something with his hands than sit and listen
Doesn't want to be in anything that feels 'like more school'
cases.clinicalGoal: Develop structured after-school and weekend activities that build social connections and executive function skills in a low-pressure environment.
cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as Ethan's parent. Your psychiatrist generated these recommendations after Ethan's last appointment.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on building/hands-on interests, coding curiosity, aversion to lecture/repetitive formats, preference for short-burst engagement, afternoon timing (post-medication), low social pressure entry point

recommendations.name: Roanoke Library - Teen Coding Club
recommendations.description: Weekly drop-in coding sessions for teens ages 13-17. Project-based format where participants build games and apps. Laptops provided. Mentor available but kids work at their own pace. Typically 4-8 teens per session.
recommendations.intake: Drop-in, no registration

recommendations.description: High school robotics team that designs, builds, and programs robots for regional competitions. Hands-on building sessions with mentors from local engineering firms. New members welcome any time. Team of 15-20 students.
recommendations.location: Innovation Lab at Patrick Henry High School, 3.1 miles away
recommendations.intake: Show up to any session, ask for the team captain

recommendations.description: Open workshop sessions for teens where participants build projects with electronics, 3D printers, and hand tools. Each session has a different theme but self-directed exploration is encouraged. No prior experience needed.
recommendations.intake: Walk in, sign waiver with parent

recommendations.description: Monthly support group for teenagers with ADHD. Facilitated discussion format covering topics like school strategies, social skills, and self-advocacy. Parents attend a concurrent group. Typically 10-15 teens.
recommendations.schedule: Second Wednesday of each month, 6:30-8:00 PM
recommendations.intake: Register through CHADD website

recommendations.name: Roanoke Parks & Recreation - Teen After-School Programs
recommendations.description: Supervised after-school drop-in programs for teens ages 13-17. Activities vary daily and include sports, games, arts and crafts, and homework help.
recommendations.location: Preston Park Community Center, 0.9 miles away
recommendations.intake: Parent signs registration form

recommendations.name: Boy Scouts Troop 117 - Roanoke Valley
recommendations.description: Traditional scouting program with weekly meetings, monthly campouts, and badge advancement. Troop of approximately 30 scouts. Activities planned by older scouts with adult oversight.
recommendations.schedule: Mondays 7:00-8:30 PM, monthly campouts on weekends
recommendations.intake: Attend a meeting with parent, complete registration paperwork

cases.presentingProblem: Diagnosed at age 11. Academically strong but increasingly socially isolated in high school. Rigid routines and difficulty with unstructured social time. Meltdowns at home have increased since starting 9th grade, primarily triggered by sensory overload and unexpected schedule changes.
cases.currentTreatment: No medication currently. Sees a psychologist biweekly for social skills and emotional regulation. Parents are primary support system.
relevantHistory: Freshman at a public high school, enrolled in honors classes
Lives with both parents and older brother (age 17)
Had one close friend in middle school who moved away last summer
Eats lunch alone in the library most days
No behavioral concerns at school but described as 'very quiet' by teachers
cases.functionalStatus: Academically high-performing but socially exhausted by the school day. Needs 1-2 hours of alone time after school to decompress. Sensory sensitivities to loud noise, bright/fluorescent lighting, and crowded spaces. Communicates well one-on-one or in writing but shuts down in groups larger than 4-5. Very organized when routine is predictable.
patientReported: Passionate about marine biology and ocean animals, can talk about it extensively
Enjoys drawing, especially detailed scientific illustrations of sea creatures
Finds most teen social activities 'too loud and confusing'
Wants friends but doesn't know how to start conversations that aren't about her interests
Prefers to know exactly what will happen at an activity before going, including who will be there
cases.clinicalGoal: Build social connections through interest-based activities in sensory-appropriate, predictable environments with small group sizes.

clinicianSettings.contraindications: Avoid loud, crowded, or unpredictable environments. Avoid activities requiring significant unscripted social interaction.

cases.viewerContext: You are reviewing this as Lily's parent. Your psychiatrist generated these recommendations after Lily's last appointment.

versionA.hidden_logic: Selected based on marine biology special interest, drawing interest, sensory needs (quiet/low-stimulation), small group size requirement, need for predictability and advance information, preference for parallel or interest-based interaction over unstructured socializing

recommendations.name: Virginia Aquarium Junior Volunteer Program
recommendations.description: Teen volunteer program at the aquarium focused on animal care and education. Volunteers work in pairs alongside a staff mentor in specific exhibit areas. Orientation includes a full walkthrough of duties and schedule before starting. Quiet behind-the-scenes areas.
recommendations.intake: Application and parent consent form, virtual orientation before first visit

recommendations.name: Art Studio 9 - Scientific Illustration for Teens
recommendations.description: Small class focused on detailed observational drawing of natural subjects. Maximum 5 students. Quiet studio with natural lighting. Instructor provides structured demonstrations followed by independent work time.
recommendations.intake: Register online, detailed syllabus and studio photos sent after registration

recommendations.name: Autism Society of Roanoke Valley - Teen Interest Groups
recommendations.description: Small special interest groups for autistic teens organized around shared topics (current groups include marine science, anime, and coding). Groups of 3-5 teens with a trained facilitator. Structured agenda shared before each meeting.
recommendations.cost: Free for members ($25 annual family membership)
recommendations.intake: Parent completes interest survey, facilitator calls family before first meeting to discuss format and expectations

versionB.hidden_logic: Selected based on proximity, adolescent age group, ASD diagnosis, structured/small-group constraint from clinician, and general availability for teens

recommendations.name: Autism Society of Roanoke Valley - Teen Social Group
recommendations.description: Biweekly structured social group for autistic teens ages 13-17. Activities follow a predictable format: check-in, planned group activity, and free time in a quiet room. 8-10 teens per session. Facilitated by a licensed social worker.
recommendations.cost: Free for members ($25 annual family membership)
recommendations.intake: Parent calls to register, intake form required

recommendations.name: Roanoke Library - Teen Creative Writing Workshop
recommendations.description: Structured 6-week workshop for teens. Guided prompts and quiet individual writing time with optional sharing at the end. Max 8 participants. Held in a small meeting room.
recommendations.intake: Registration required, curriculum shared in advance

recommendations.name: Blue Ridge Nature Journal Club for Teens
recommendations.description: Monthly nature journaling meetup where teens sketch and document local wildlife at outdoor sites. Quiet, self-directed activity with a naturalist guide. Groups of 5-8.
recommendations.schedule: First Saturday of each month, 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM
recommendations.intake: Registration required, location shared one week in advance
